ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Labs could have included more self-driven analysis and problem solving. For example, we could have been given a scenario for a type of question we wanted to solve and then had to apply the topic of the day. I enjoyed working on my own study site for several of the labs and appreciated the length of time we had to work on our projects.
Great course if you need to learn about remote sensing
I love this class
Dr. Joshi's jokes, quotes and banter. And lab assignments.
Joshi was a really wonderful professor and was a lot of fun to learn from. He was really responsive to student interests, and really cared that we learned the material.
Professor Joshi.
This course is very practical and the instructor is experienced in real-life operations which is quite beneficial to my own research.
the instructor

Learning a new skill, classes by Professor Joshi, laboratory sections, student projects. Professor Joshi himself--what a great professor! I wish he taught here full time. He is an amazing resource, and especially friendly and happy to engage with students.
Are the lab works, the guest lectures and the mini project at the end of the class.
The lab sessions. Take the most you can from the CEO and Mr. Larry.
Great lectures, lab work was relevant to the course.
Joshi!!!
I learned all theories, and techniques in a logical way

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: More thought-provoking labs.
The tests (especially midterm) focused way too much on small details rather than the overall process. While I learned the general material, I had not memorized minute details that were on the exams.
I think this class is fine as it is.

Laying out expectations for what course is about more clearly at the beginning of the course. I was under the impression that the course would be more practical than theoretical but found it fairly heavy on the theory side. This is fine if the expectations are laid out accordingly from the beginning.
the TAs weren't too familiar with the software so that was annoying
Can organize the application part more.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Very strong availability and high quality of help. I visited Dr. Joshi several times during office hours and spoke with Eliza outside of class for help.
Always very helpful!
Good!
I received a lot of help from the instructor, it's great!

I was frustrated with the TA for my lab section; doing the laboratory exercises before we arrived (or even with us) would have been more helpful than sitting there doing other work. She put very little effort into labs.Professor Joshi's help was excellent, I appreciated that he came in late in the afternoon or even on weekends just to see who was in the lab.He was always available in his office as well.
The instructor was very helpful.The TFs were very helpful and knowledgeable about the course .
Excelent, they were very responsive.
Prof. Joshi always willing to take time to meet in the office or the computer lab.
Great responsiveness from TAs and the instructor.
Instructor very much available, TAs during lab hours only
very responsive

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Will provide analysis techniques for my PhD research.
This gave me all the skills I need for my masters project.
I hope that there will be more applications about remote sensing
Very useful technical skills
I hope to take more course in Remote Sensing and use it to study climate change and land use change. I hope FES offers more courses in Remote Sensing
Remote sensing has a vast application base. Its applicable to almost all fields of study making it very useful to me where forest resources management is concerned.
If you're interested in resource management / GIS / physical studies, this is a must.
I'm interested in measuring biomass at landscape level, so remote sensing is clearly very helpful
I might not need RS skill for my research. But I think it will be useful someday for me.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To acquire analysis skills for my PhD research.
I just wanted to add remote sensing to my list of skills!
My masters project.
It's highly related to my current research project
To learn remote sensing so I can use it in my research
To learn the remote sensing techniques and to become at least literate in it if not an expert.
I always considered that Remote sensing is a powerful tool. And it is.
I thought it would be interesting, relevant for environmental managers, and a good skill to know and have on my resume.
see 15
I want to learn more about remote sensing

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes.
Yes
Yes
Yes, I think so
Yes

YES! I am really appreciative that Professor Joshi was able to come spend the semester at FES. He is an incredible professor(and very modest), but it was a lucky opportunity for us to learn from such an expert.
yes it did
Yes, of course.
Yes, exceeded my expectations.
yes
Yes.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
yes
Yes, definitely
Mostly
Yes, thank you Professor Joshi and FES for making this possible
yes I did
Not that much because we had a 30% final exam. Instead, it should have been a 50% final project.
Yes
yes
I hope it is a two semester class

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Not many advantages except that we were able to divide up the work... challenging to coordinate our busy schedules.
It was okay, but the assignments didn't really add much to be honest.
We can brainstorm together
Presentations of group work were helpful to understand what other students were learning. Group work can be challenging in general to organize, but it was a good opportunity to learn and meet others.
Group work is real life. The better you have in grad school, the best.
Good to be able to talk about difficult material.
I enjoyed working in groups but found some of the group assignments to be overly tedious.
good to exchange ideas and share software tricks
A happy environment to learn

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Read the book and really understand the labs, don't ust follow the instructions.
It's worth your time!!

Study differently for this course than you usually do--focus on memorizing details, like formulas and numbers, as well as applications. Anticipate pop quizes. Think about how you want to use Remote Sensing in the future and use your project to explore something that interests you--prepare to spend a lot of time on it.
Do the lab works and you will learn a lot, until you apply what you are learning in class in the lab you will not gain the most out of the remote sensing course.
Take the final project very seriously. Else you'll be wasting your time because the concepts reviewed in class are very abstract.

We had a visiting professor from India, so course is probably pretty different with regular teacher. Spend time understanding the theoretical background material in RS - it will save time and energy in the long run.
This was a very good course with broad applications.
It's worthwhile course (you can take GIS anywhere, but not remote sensing), although the instructor next year will be different...
try to think harder and participate more
